Award.AwardTitle: Nets: Small: Optimal Design of Anonymous Network Systems under Resource Constraints

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Privacy in networked systems goes beyond the secrecy of exchanged data; it is equally critical to protect the identities of communicating parties and the paths of data flow. Availability of such networking information is not only a violation of user privacy, but also provides a convenient platform for a malicious adversary to launch more powerful attacks. Anonymous network systems are networks of special routers and proxy servers that provide protection using cryptographic tools and covert relaying. Commonly deployed systems are, however, vulnerable to timing analysis of packet transmissions and do not provide the necessary protection under resource limitations.

The principal investigators will investigate the provably optimal design of anonymous network systems under constraints on resources and desired network quality of service (QoS). They will develop a novel quantitative measure of anonymity that takes into account the complete information available to an adversary and the resource and topological constraints of a network. Using the quantitative model, they will explore the following three critical problems in network system design: optimal resource allocation, stochastic routing, and topological design. If successful, the analysis will give rise to novel networking algorithms to achieve anonymity in information exchange that cater to modern paradigms of network design such as mobility and application independence.

Broader Impact: The research will have a significant impact in delivering provable privacy for networked systems. The research promotes graduate and undergraduate education in network security and provides access to recent advances in the field to community college students and law enforcement personnel through distance learning programs. In addition, awareness of security vulnerabilities in social networks will be broadened for middle to high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
n the Information Age that we live in today, data dissemination has never been faster, and the speed and volume of the impact of such dissemination have grown lepas and bounds. From a scientific perspective, information theory provided the means to quantify information which eventually led to striking advances in communication technologies that fueled this revolution.  In today's highly connected world, controlling the impact of information communicated is as important as controlling the amount of information communicated. It is essential that we are aware and are provided control in the quality and quantity of sensitive information communicated. Although users retain the choice in deciding what to communicate and when, protocols and media of communication can expose sensitive information inadvertantly, as demonstrated by the timing vulnerability which motivated this project. The broad objectives of this project are to understand theoretically the vulnerabilities of present networked systems, and provide insights into the design of future networked systems. The key outcomes of this project are summarized below:

1. Obtained a quantitative understanding of the tradeoffs between Anonymity of network users, and the tangible performance of the network system, as measured by delays, amount of memory required, and fairness across users.

2. Developed novel protocols for network devices (such as routers) that allow network participants to operate on any desired point on the tradeoff curves (their choice of balancy between security and utility). These protocols outperformed state-of-the-art algorithms for provisioning anonymity. The efficacy of the protocols were also demonstrated on state-of-the-art network emulators. 

3. Derived mathematical insights into topological structure of networks and the ability of the network devices to provide a desired degree of anonymity for the participants. 

4. The theoretical methodologies derived adapted techniques across different domains including statistical signal processing, information theory, game theory and stochastic control, providing new insights into the application of existing methodologies.

5. Increased awareness of the research topic and goals, by disseimnating the novel research results to the peer scientific groups, the Lehigh community, and the broader public through different avenues including peer-reviewed publications, magazine articles, and outreach programs involving middle and high school students.

6. The project provided the opportunity for graduate students to work on their PhD thesis research. The technical outcomes of this project formed a significant part of two Phd theses, by Abhishek Mishra (who defended his PhD thesis in 2014) and Omid Javidbakht (who will likely defend in 2016). The project provided opportunities for the students to present their research to peers in reputed IEEE and ACM conferences, in addition to being trained in technical writing through dissemination in peer-reviewed journals.

7. Three undergraduate students were provided summer research opportunities through this project. Their participation in research discussions and activities related to the topic of anonymity and stochastic control exposed them to cutting edge methodologies and encouraged them to pursue graduate education, and a possible career in R&D.
